"I'm 27 years old. I've no money and no prospects. I'm already a burden to my parents, and I'm frightened." Who says vintage romantic fiction isn't relatable? Making cinematic adaptations of historical literature is a dangerous game. There's name recognition in the title, sure, but it's a tightrope walk between making dated source material appealing to a mass audience, and meeting the expectations of the vocal and rabidly dedicated base of readers that insist on nothing short of absolute accuracy. This 2005 Joe Wright adaptation (shockingly only the second cinematic version of the Jane Austen novel, the former predating this one by 65 years) could never hope to do justice to all of the intricate character designs and subplots of the full novel by virtue of runtime alone, and instead opts for alterations in structure and writing in order to give the film more popular appeal while staying true to the base premise and the romantic intrigues of the novel. With excellent casting and period details that together make characters seem empathetic and relatable rather than relics of another time, Pride & Prejudice slides only slightly when it comes to the risks that its characters undertake (which never feel that daring), but retains solid footing as a period romance; I particularly liked Donald Sutherland and the underrated Brenda Blethyn as Mr. and Mrs. Bennet, such a charming, loving, and slightly eccentric couple, even if they were made to be more rustic than Austen intended. There are lots of things to like about this adaption! Firstly, music score which threads through the story so well, helping to pull it together as does the excellent use of the locations with the grand houses, gardens and countryside being stars in the movie in their own right. The two lead performances are excellent. Knightly deserved her Oscar nomination. She truly embodied Lizzie's wit, warmth, humour and frustrations and that she did so whilst challenged by a much diminished amount of dialogue and much fewer opportunities than afforded by a TV series was remarkable. In this she is assisted by the script which retains sufficient elements from the book to achieve this end but the romance is certainly helped along by both Knightly and McFadyen being equally as God as Firth and Ehle at acting with their eeyes and having the right chemistry. Some standout scenes for me are the two dancing together in an a suddenly empty room, the hand flex scene and the scene where the sisters are excited post the ball and chatting together in bed! Brought back many happy memories of sleepovers at the homes of my friends and chatting excitedly post party etc. Rosamund Pike is very good at capturing Jane's goodness and tolerance and her pain at 'losing' Bingley, despite her being under used. There are many scenes or characters totally removed or only referenced but these removals are well chosen and the core elements and themes of the book remain in the movie. I have mixed feelings about Wickham being hardly on screen, certainly he is not present enough for the viewer to hate him. Afterall, he is the pantomime villain of the tale. Who doesn't want a proper opportunity to internally boo and hiss at him? Unfortunately, we don't get it here but I confess when re-watching the series I often fast forward through the bits with him in, so perhaps Wickham is on screen quite enough. Mr and Mrs Bennett are much softened around the edges here, with still sufficient of the character's faults found in the book to lead to the the inevitable social embarrassments and Lydia's stupidity but Mr Bennett here shows genuine regret that he hurts his wife when siding with Lizzie on the occasion of Lizzie refusing Mr Collins and his wife also demonstrates real fondness for him, rather than false flattery or nagging to get her way. I like this portrayal whilst not considering it superior to the more colder portrait of the relationship in the book Mary and Kitty are also more kindly treated here and I confess i like the nice touch of this movie showing them becoming closer after Lydia is out of the picture. I do wish there was more Darcy! Yet MacFadyen and the script still do him justice portraying a man who's a bit shy and determined to preserve his dignity and yet deeply loyal, very honourable and loving. The proposal scene, so different from the book and other dramatisations, is nevertheless moving and his expression when Lizzie refuses him! It's actually heart breaking! Even though you are, as you should be, annoyed with his arrogant, basically insulting proposal you do recognise that he is truly attached to her. I know that the portrayal of Bingley is criticised. Quite a few of my friends don't like it. The proposal preparation scene and actual proposal is well done, as is the scene where he gets too scared to propose when he first turns up and the ballroom scenes I also like. However, I have to agree that some scenes, most especially those at Netherfield when interacting with his sister and Darcy are almost painful. The actor plays him almost like a dim-witted buffoon. That hee hee school boy laugh really grates and his expression often looks vacant and daft. This is unfortunate as on other occasions he does a good job of playing the role but I was rather annoyed by those scenes. Overall though it's an excellent version of the book staying true to its core and often being genuinely moving. When Lizzie cries after receiving Jane's letter I cried too. Her pain felt so real.

Summary: The movie tells the romantic story of a young lady who lives in a small town in England in the 19th century. The story begins when two young and rich men arrive in town. One of them is a gentle, kind person who everyone loves, but on the contrary, his friend, though visibly good-looking and rich, seems to be proud and arrogant. The young lady, Elizabeth Bennet, calls the attention of the arrogant rich man, Mr. Darcy. She, however, has a terrible first impression of him that makes her decide she would never marry a man like him. After some time, Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy meet again and he confesses his love for her, telling her he has tried in vain to repress what he feels for her, and even with her inferiority of class he has concluded that he loves her. Elizabeth rejects his offer to marry him, feeling offended by his words, but soon after that, she reflects on the offer she has just lost. After some time, while Elizabeth is traveling she gets to know his sister and people who work for him. She then is admired by the profound respect all of them have for him, considering him a generous, kind, unselfish, and caring person. She then admires him and more profoundly regrets having rejected him the first time. At the same time, Mr. Darcy repents of having thought of Elizabeth as an inferior-class person and learns to recognize her for who she really is. The last event that helps Elizabeth reflect is that when her little sister causes a scandal after flying off with a military officer, Mr. Darcy anonymously helps to solve the problem. This last event brings a new opportunity to meet again with Mr. Darcy, who she now respects and admires. He proposes her marriage for the second time and she now accepts. Analysis: The themes that Pride and Prejudice analyzes are gender, class, and reputation. The story occurs at a time when women had rigid roles and were expected to fulfill them. For example, marriage was the only thing that Elizabeth's mother and friends were worried about. This is because at that time, marriage was the only way in which a woman could have economic stability. The movie recognizes and criticizes the gender injustices that were present at that time. The principal character, Elizabeth Bennet, rejects two marriage offers showing that she knew she was capable of remain independent until she wanted to marry someone she really loved, not just because of money and need. Another theme mentioned in this movie is class and reputation. A woman's reputation was the most important for society. Women were expected to behave such that they would always look good. For example, there is a time when Elizabeth appears with muddy clothes and people appear to be uncomfortable with that. Another example comes when Elizabeth's sister escapes with an officer without being married; this completely destroys her reputation and even the reputation of his entire family. The movie again goes against the ideas of that epoch. The movie exaggerates some class boundaries in order to ridicule some behaviors and make them seem absurd. However, it also recognizes and accepts other less formal class boundaries. Critique/Recommendation: I personally love Pride and Prejudice movie. The adaptation from Jane Austen's book is amazing; the sensibility of the film makes it sweet and enjoyable. It also helps you to understand how society was established and the roles women played in society in the 19th century. Along with that, you enjoy the beautiful love story of two and more characters. This is a perfect movie to enjoy with your family or a group of girlfriends. I fell in love with this movie the first time I saw it and could watch it again a thousand times. I highly recommend it and would give it 5/5 stars.

Never let your pride pass by your prejudice! Little do I know about Jane Austen's novel from 1813 named Pride & Prejudice. There is no such thing as too many awards for this 2005 film because, hey! The film only took two decades to finally be released? Besides we know that this is no modern story since it's been originally written in the 19th century. However, Joe Wright's film is only one way of interpretation of Jane Austen's novel. I, for example, liked his interpretation. Or should I say loved ? Yet I must admit the reached length of the film as it is quite long. Roughly two hours to be correct. Nonetheless it does have its advantage and disadvantage. You can enjoy the film for a longer amount of time and the story definitely could have been put in a film of shorter length as it would be, I think, more powerful. I'm sure you've seen at least one romantic drama whose story takes place in the 21st century. If I'm right then you should know that those movies are pretty predictable, which by the way, doesn't necessarily makes them inferior. It's just that these movies usually have the same build-up of storyline compared to the unique course of Pride&Prejudice. That's how many other movies have been inspired by this story, such as Becoming Jane, Bright star and several other movies. The first half of the movie was kind of confusing to me, not because I didn't understand what was going on but because I didn't know what to expect the end to be like. I enjoyed it nevertheless. In fact, this kept my tension up because I couldn't predict what would happen afterwards. The not too exciting progress of the film is besides what made the ending so special, beautiful and outstanding. I was surprised to say so. Elizabeth Bennet played by Keira Knightley an Mr. Darcy played by Matthew Macfadyen are the main characters of this film. They performed charismatic and splendid. It is not always as easy to live according to the standards of the 19th century as a modern person, but they have certainly succeeded. Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy form a prejudice about each other after an inconvenient meeting at a public ball. They meet several times afterwards, but no one is willing to take the first step towards getting to know each other better as their pride dominates and because of their difference in class. Despite their persistence they still get to discover each other's true personalities. This simultaneously leads to the end of the film and the start of a new story. Something that really took my attention is the remarkable acting of Matthew while representing Mr. Darcy. Many people do not really appreciate his acting opposed to what I see in his performance. I could sense the absence of Mr. Darcy's emotions and mainly face expressions during most of the film. As the film continued we got to see how he flourished and exposed more and more of his emotions. So we surely did get rewarded for our patience. Even more surprising is how some of his emotions were perfectly expressed by his words. Truly admirable. On top of that there is also the time aspect of the film. The story took place in the 18th century and I really got to see how a love story, mainly revolving around marriages, could occur in that time. It was the first time I got to see something like that which was very interesting. The film crew created the ideal setting for the story and it clearly paid off and added depth to the story. As if all of that wasn't enough, humour was included as well. This is what completed the film for me. I personally like an additional touch of humour. Finally, I have to say that this movie left me with a smile on my face. Not many movies can do that to me. This is a classic that you can't miss out. Joe Wright is a hit and miss director for me as Darkest Hour (2017) and Pan (2015) are ghastly films and yet I am quite a fan of Atonement (2007) and this film although they feel very sub-Merchant Ivory at times. This, his first big hit, launched him as a successful director of middle brow prestige dramas and it's easy to see why as he blends the style of Jane Austen's classic text with modern sensibilities more palatable to young audiences. I personally like the film although it never reaches the heights of great period romances like The Age of Innocence (1993) and A Room with a View (1985). This is the sort of film that will reliably entertain teenage girls who enjoy pomp and pageantry but don't want to have to deal with all of the hard to understand, old fashioned language that can sometimes accompany films of this sort. Young Elizabeth Bennett, Keira Knightley, is encouraged to marry by her social climbing mother Mrs. Bennett, Brenda Blethyn, so that she may obtain financial security. She meets the socially awkward Mr. Darcy, Matthew Mcfadyen, at a party held by her Charles Bingley, Simon Woods, the suitor of her attractive and sensible sister Jane, Rosamund Pike. The two immediately clash although she develops romantic feelings for him over time. After rejecting the proposal of Mr. Collins, Tom Hollander, Bennett is angered by Darcy as he encourages Bingley not to marry her sister, an action which frustrates her as Jane is left saddened. When Darcy does admit his feelings she reveals her long held grievances against him and the two argue fiercely but are eventually able to set aside their differences and end up married. Unlike the cold and stuffy Sense and Sensibility (1995) this film gets the warmth of Austen's novels write as the characters are humorous and the film acknowledges the absurdities of Victorian society. The characters here feel like real human beings although Mr. Darcy is a bit of a female fantasy what with his being wealthy and rich and only slightly socially inept. Screenwriter Deborah Moggach retains the bare bones of the novel but updates a lot of the themes and ideas to suit a 2005 audience watching the film. For example, the sisters bicker and fight in this film without using the flowery language present in the novel and add in a bit of elbowing for good measure. While we can trust that this is probably not how young women living during this time period interacted we can also feel comfortable knowing that we understand what their bond is and we are not lost looking up old timey language. For fans of Downton Abbey this may not be acceptable but for audiences less likely to enjoy Maggie Smith reprimanding feisty young upstarts this film caters to their needs. The acting in the film is also understated but rather marvelous as Knightley makes her first foray into period dramas, the genre with which she would become closely associated with. She is a feisty Bennett with fierce intelligence and frustrations with the restrictions that the world around her place upon her but she's not too fiery or angry as she remains as subdued and repressed as you would expect a woman of this time period to be. Blethyn fares well as Mrs. Bennett who is a delight even as she schemes to sell her daughters off while Donald Sutherland is a reliably sage benevolent presence as their loving father. Mcfadyen is decent as Darcy as he and Knightley have a lovely chemistry and he does bring a certain brooding chemistry to the role that Colin Firth did not. The acting is never spectacular but it fits the middle of the road style that the film adopts as it is uniformly pleasant while never blowing you away. If you are looking for originality or inventiveness this is not the film to turn to but if you like fairly traditional costume dramas then this will fulfill your desires. This film also yielded the first of Knightley's two Academy Award nominations and displays why she would be such a dominant force in the genre over the next decade as she looks lovely, has a bright, cheery presence and a surprising talent for comedy. An essential watch for fans of Knightley.

Pride & Prejudice is everything I expected it to be. Jane Austen stories have this glamorous view of Georgian England, and it is delightful to enter that world for a couple of hours. This particular story is a complex one because there are many sisters involved and their relationships all seem to intersect with one another in some fashion. I’ll admit that I lost track of some of the story, and even found myself looking for a cheat sheet on the internet about halfway through. There are a couple reasons I got confused. First of all, the way they speak using dialogue that is sort of period specific, it can make it hard to understand everything they are saying (and half the time they avoid saying what they are thinking because they don’t want to show any impropriety.) The other problem I had was that I never learned all the women’s names early on. As a result, when they would refer to Jane, Mary, Charlotte, and so forth, I would struggle to follow who they were talking about. At the heart of all this drama is the unlikely pair of Elizabeth Bennet and Mr. Darcy (the two names I absolutely knew.) Keira Knightley is the same radiant beauty I always expect, who lights up the screen every time she is there. Even when my brain was struggling with the story, my heart was connected to it because she had me invested. But Matthew Macfadyen was a little bland as Darcy. I kept trying to decipher if this was on purpose because he was playing the character as stoic and emotionally reserved, or if he isn’t that good of an actor. The scenes where he wasn’t holding back what he truly thought made me suspect he might just be a mediocre actor. I simply didn’t believe he was as head-over-heels in love as he said. Even with a lesser performance from the male lead, I enjoyed the primary romance story. There’s something so pleasant about films based on Jane Austen books. I found myself getting swept up in the charm of Pride & Prejudice even when the plot escaped me. I bet if I rewatched it, now that I know what’s happening, I would like it even more.

Proving that sometimes a single 2-hour movie adaptation isn't enough to do a novel justice, Pride & Prejudice ends up being beautifully shot, well-acted but emotionally stunted. I admire the talent involved, and for me Donald Sutherland was the absolute best thing about it. His sense of humour, his ease at shifting between moods, the way he interacts with his onscreen family, I thought he was great. Unfortunately, as becomes quickly apparent, there's a reason this worked better as a 6-part miniseries than as a feature film. The novel is long and complex in its exploration of societal expectations and how a person can be blinded by the words of its title. Darcy's gradual emotional shift is very abrupt, as he jumps from looking down his nose at Elizabeth to expressing his love for her so quickly that it just comes across as rushed and unconvincing. Also Mr. Darcy's expression changes little throughout the film, suggesting either the actor has trouble smiling or the Director told him not too. Also it suffers that problem endemic to films based in England in this time period, in that characters use twice as many words as necessary to say very simple things, such as 'It would be most inappropriate of you to accept such an impertinent invitation' rather than 'No you shouldn't.' It might sound like I'm dogpiling on the film, but it's still a nice watch. It just fails to live up to the standards of its source material, but given the time constraints, it's understandable. And since very few movies live up to the books on which they're based, Pride & Prejudice deserves credit for making the best effort it could.

It's a well-known tale from Jane Austen back in the early 19th century. In a society where the only thing anybody seems to think about is finding a good suitor for his or her children, Mr. and Mrs. Bennet are busy with five daughters to stress about. Lucky for them, one of their five, Lizzie (Keira Knightley), has a good enough grasp on her own independence to figure things out for herself. If you can understand the British lilt accompanying the archaic repartee used throughout much of this film, then more power to you. Luckily, it doesn't hinder my ability to comprehend the main story, but the problem lies in the lighthearted banter that picks up the mood between dramatic ambits. Some things may get lost in translation, but it gets its point across. Matthew MacFadyen does well as the famed Mr. Darcy. When you first see him on screen, he's so cold that you have no idea how that man is capable of love of any kind. He and Knightley's chemistry grows as their characters' does. Lizzie, being from a more middle-class family, and Mr. Darcy, a wealthy personage of significance, have unspoken tensions and reservations about each other regarding financial status. And obviously, the point is that we should look past superficial attraction and at true character. However, this is derailed a bit as director Joe Wright's order of things gives us some reason to believe that Lizzie could, in fact, be falling in love with Mr. Darcy for those exact reasons. I assure you, this is far from Austen's original intent. Nonetheless, this 2005 adaptation means well and is a classic piece of modern cinema. It may not be my first choice of drama to watch on any given day, but the impressive performances by the whole cast, along with the very consistent pacing make for an enjoyable watch. The beautiful scenery and set pieces are a plus, providing a pleasurable watch all the way to the end. Twizard Rating: 96

Rumpled clothes,bare feet, loose ratty hair, and farm animals in the house are not Austen. Elizabeth Bennet was feisty, not bipolar. The film's attempt to cram this rich story into a commercial-length film -- and appeal to non-Austen readers -- resulted in sudden, inexplicable character turns. I felt that both leading roles were excruciatingly miscast. (Although I have enjoyed them in other films.) And Donald Sutherland -- an actor whose work I have much admired in the past -- turned in one of the most humorless performances I have witnessed on film. Austen was anything but humorless. But the engagement announcement scene between Mr. Bennet and Elizabeth was excruciating to watch, more befitting a man having a nervous breakdown than one sharing joy with his most beloved daughter. I have seen many Austen movies -- both the costume-drama ilk and the modern adaptations and enjoyed them immensely. It seems to me that this particular production suffered an identity crisis in trying to adapt Austen whilst leaving Austen out of it almost entirely.

People who go for this sort of thing will find Pride and Prejudice exactly the sort of thing that they go for. People who don't go for this sort of thing will get exactly the sort of thing they expect - and yet there's a very good chance that they'll still find some enjoyment in Pride and Prejudice. Transcending beyond the assumed audience is key for a movie like this. Because lets be honest, a (somewhat) stuffy 18th century drama about love between two levels of the British class system is not something that would tickle the fancy of most male moviegoers. And yet this movie, at least for me, was entirely enjoyable and far better than most films of similar ilk. And I guess the movie has Jane Austen to thank for that. I was required to read the 1813 novel (that this movie is an adaption of ... bet you couldn't have figured that one out) this year for school. What started out as a requirement quickly turned into something genuinely enjoyable, much to my chagrin. My preconceived notion of the book turned out to be completely false. In its place, I found a witty, sarcastic, endearing, and engrossing novel that brought me to the realization that, "maybe this book is popular for a reason." I really enjoyed Pride and Prejudice. And yet, going into this movie, I had the same expectations. Sure, by that point I knew that the director, Joe Wright, had great source material to work with. But than the classic question arose, "how can they adapt a book that's three or four hundred pages long into a two hour movie?" I twice doubted this story, and I was twice proven wrong. I'm still not quite sure how the filmmakers were able to cram so much into this movie, but I can't deny that they do. It's a streamlined version, but everything that was significant in the novel is brought successfully onto the screen. I really enjoyed Pride and Prejudice yet again! The story revolves around Elizabeth and Jane Bennet, and their relationships with Charles Bingley and his friend, Mr. Darcy. Elizabeth and Jane are charming individuals, but they live below the upper class. Bingley and Darcy are rich, and the latter gives off a distinct aura of contemptibility. The story masterfully intertwines a couple of different interpersonal relationships. As I mentioned before, screenwriter Deborah Moggach and director Joe Wright do an exceptional job of condensing are rather large book into a concise and digestible movie. Because the vast majority of the book is just conversations, you can tell that Wright made the conscious effort to add interesting aspects to these scenes of dialogue. For instance, in the classic first marriage proposal scene between Elizabeth and Darcy - Wright moves the action from simply inside a house in broad daylight, to rain and overcast skies, outside, under a beautiful stone gazebo. It's little tweaks like this that add a certain level of freshness to this well-known story. Wright also uses very slight zoom-ins during scenes of dialogue. They feel a bit weird, but they do bring focus to important parts of scenes. I'm guessing that was his aim. In addition, the cinematography present here turns simple shots into things of beauty. The performances in this movie are spot-on, and casting in this movie is pitch perfect! I'm not just talking Keira Knightley and Matthew Macfadyen (who are both fantastic!). No, the filmmakers here are totally in tuned with each and every character. Starting at the top, Keira Knightley was worthily awarded an Academy Award nomination for her performance as Lizzy Bennet. It's not really out of her range to play a classical character like this - she's done it many a time - but she is, nonetheless, very good. Matthew Macfadyen is not only playing a fantastic character, but he's also playing him fantastically well. While both Darcy and Elizabeth have unique character arcs throughout the story, I think Darcy's is the more difficult task to pull off. And Macfadyen is up to the challenge. He can be thoroughly unlikable at times, but the good heart of the character manages to shine through as the movie progresses. In casting Elizabeth's sisters, Joe Wright seemed to have had a knack for plucking talented actresses before their careers took off. Lydia and Kitty are played by Jena Malone and Carey Mulligan. Long before Malone started lighting up the screen as Johanna Mason in The Hunger Games, she was totally embodying the frivolous and shallow Lydia Bennet. And long before Mulligan was playing Daisy opposite Leonardo DiCaprio's Jay Gatsby, she was making her film debut as Kitty. Rosamund Pike is given perhaps the most uninteresting character in the movie. In both the book and the movie, Jane is 100% good natured throughout the entire duration. Still, Pike does what she can with the material. The Bennet parents are both played to the hilt, but in different ways. Brenda Blethyn is disgustingly shallow as Mrs. Bennet ... exactly as she was in the book. And playing my favorite character in the movie, Mr. Bennet, Donald Sutherland does what he always does. He's such a phenomenal actor, and Mr. Bennet is such a funny character. He definitely has the funniest lines in the movie! In addition, Tom Hollander, Judi Dench, and Kelly Reilly are all perfectly cast in supporting roles. Dario Marianelli's score rises above the genre standard for classical scores for historical movies. It's become one of the most iconic things about the film. His theme for piano that often crops up, played by the actors on screen, is excellent. The score is well worthy of the Oscar nomination it received. Sometimes, low expectations can be a movie's best friend. Sometimes, being thoroughly well made can propel a movie beyond one or two shortcomings. And sometimes, a movie that fits squarely into the last genre in the world that would appeal to this reviewer, actually turns out to be a great film! "Well, if Jane does die, it will be a comfort to know she was in pursuit of Mr. Bingley." 8/10

I basically watched it on a dare -- and because it's one of my friends favorite movies. Pride and Prejudice is not the typical film I would endeavor to watch. In the past I've called myself a film connoisseur, but in reality I'm merely an overly qualified movie fan. And something of a film snob. I've never entertained the idea that I have enough time to waste watching film after film if it does not, in some way immediately spark my interest. Hence the reason why I refrain from viewing more than one superhero movie a year. In the case of Pride and Prejudice, my prejudice came in the form of period costume drama. I had not the patience nor the desire to sit down for two hours watching people speak in polite, rhetorical fashion which preserves both posterity and class distinction in their understanding. In other words, it sounded boring as hell. This is where the dare came in. In fact, it was less the dare and more the understanding of my dear friend's love for the picture which ultimately lured me into Ms. Austen's talons; for I was swept away by this film as prey to the hunter. To alleviate the curiosity of any reader who may have found there way to this summary, I shall explain the dare: The film, Pride and Prejudice was lent to me by a friend (different friend but just as dear) who procured it from her local library. Along with this film she borrowed a another upon my suggested, entitled "Invasion of the Body Snatchers" (yes, the 1956 cold war-era science fiction thriller). I had previously explained to her the greatness of "Body Snatchers" and delved slightly into its allegorical subtext, ensuring her that this film is indeed of a rare and bygone quality. Knowing that this was a film which stirred great affection from the friend previously mentioned, Liane (friend with the library card) offered to let my borrow the film from her. A night after I had been given "Pride and Prejudice", I received a message from Liane which said that her husband, Dennis expressed an irreconcilable indifference to the idea of a film which dealt in an alien race who has come to take over humanity. I thus told Liane that if Dennis watches "Body Snatchers" I would watch "Prejudice". Thence the dare I mentioned earlier. I found the film to be difficult to penetrate at first (as most films are which deal in this particular period). Upon further viewing it was easy to allow myself to become entangled in the headstrong and brashly mouthed Elizabeth Bennet and the quiet and oft misunderstood Mr. Darcy. I dare say I found myself strapped to my seat, deeply engaged with the film and look forward to viewing it again to extract its deeper levels of meaning.

Pride and Prejudice seemed like a good film on the surface but I got lost within it and was unable to find a way out. The problem is that the story is incredibly slow moving and along the way so many dynamics occur, but if you fail to comprehend even one of the the entire series of events becomes utterly confusing and barely comprehendible, and so it barely becomes worthy of the audience's efforts to sit through it. By the end of the film I didn't know what had happened or who it had happened to, but either way it was just confusing and I don't enjoy viewing Pride and Prejudice, because amongst the excess of confusion is a slow moving plot and when it draws to a close the story seems to have moved as far as to the house next door and was largely an unproductive bore. I think part of it is the fact that I've never read the book Pride and Prejudice and I'm unaware of the cultural significance the story has, but whatever it is isn't apparent to me because essentially I found the film to be much like the film Little Women, although not nearly as thought-provoking or developmentally focused in my opinion. Basically, Pride and Prejudice didn't make me think and just made me bored, and it had many long and directionless scenes which seemed just to be there as a decent looking sequence to pass the time without dialogue to provide entertainment. Basically, Pride and Prejudice is a film that requires multiple viewings to grasp the story, but I was so bored the first time that I'm not eager to try again anytime soon. And I just think that it was a film insightful into a woman's mind but didn't give me information, so it's just not my ideal thing. Although it wasn't the most pleasant feature, it did have benefits. Namely, the production values are good and the film is well shot and benefits from a strong musical score which embodies the intended beautiful atmosphere which is obviously present at many points in the film. And Keira Knightly makes a fine lead role, capturing the passion of a young woman with an emotional grasp on her character and flawlessly confident line delivery. Pride and Prejudice features one of her absolute finest performances and indeed it is worth witnessing the film if not to examine the skill of its adaptation, but to be one to see Keira Knightly in one of her finest roles, worthy of recognition by the Academy Awards themselves as it scored her a well-deserved nomination for Best Actress. So i don't know what Pride and Prejudice does for its original source novel, and it does require multiple viewings, and even though I found it slow and dull it still was well crafted and finely acted.

Pride and Prejudice by Jane Austen is one of the best romantic stories I've ever read. The love between Elizabeth and the mysterious Mr. Darcy is incredible. The way the story goes about showing their love though words and awkward meetings is refreshing when we think of some of today's so called loves stories. The movie version of Pride and Prejudice that came out in 2005 directed by Joe Wright is a true masterpiece.First, lets discuss the amazing casting for this film. Starting with the lovely and talented Keira Knightley. She was perfect for the role. Her tomboyish beauty is what makes her, in my opinion, the perfect Elizabeth Bennet. She has an independent way about her that fits perfectly with the original character of Elizabeth. Matthew Macfadyen was also a great Mr. Darcy. His evolution throughout the film is the greatest of any in the movie. Though he seems harsh in the beginning we learn he is misunderstood and painfully shy. Matthew acts like a man pretending not be a hopeless romantic puppy through out half the film making every women fall in love with him instantly. And the way the two reacts to one another is perfect. They have a subtle sexual tension throughout the whole film that makes the movie 12 times better. They both react to each others actions so well to the point where the audience can clearly see they love one another before either character actually realizes that face. For example, the scene in the rain where Elizabeth states that Mr. Darcy is the "last man in the world" she could ever be married too is the most intense scene in this film. The rain, though some may say is clique, I find it to be perfect (even though it is slightly clique). That moment when they stare at each other is filled with sexual tension. The audience fully expects them to embrace one another and share a long passionate kiss. Darcy leans in, as Elizabeth does the same. He turns his head and the audience is sitting at the edge of their seat only to hear Darcy utter "Sorry, for taking up so much of your time." The first time I saw this I was shocked! In movies set in today's time period the two characters would have kissed. However, because it is a classic story the two must walk away, longing and pretending to be indifferent. The actors and actresses in the whole film are perfectly cast and wonderful, however, without Knightly and Macfadyen, this movie wouldn't have been such a success.This movie also excels due to its amazing camera work. As I continue to write more blogs you will all see that I love camera work. Me and the camera are intimately involved. In this film the setting is simply breath taking and Wright does a great job of showing the beautiful scenery he has. The long takes are the best in this film. Particularly when Mr. Darcy is walking up to Elizabeth towards the end of the film. The camera stays on him for a good minute and a half. The director could have made cuts back and forth between him and Elizabeth. Or he could have made Mr. Darcy's walk much shorter. Instead, he plays the beautiful piano in the background (thanks to Dario Marianelli) and Macfadyen walks toward the camera with the wind in his air. This scene is what I like to call subtly dramatic. You don't realize the drama in the scene until it ends and you think "man that was the most epic walk across a field I have ever seen". The close-ups in this film also show the simple beauty in the story. It causes the audience to be absorbed into the film in a way that makes you feel like you are standing in the field or in the rain watching the characters right in front of you.Overall, this movie is excellent Granted, I can understand if its not for everyone. Some people might not enjoy the whole 'old English' theme. However, the love story of this film is a good one and that is undeniable. It shows how you cannot judge a person based on loose first impressions and you need to open yourself up to the best love possible. Towards the beginning of the film, Elizabeth tells Jane "Only the deepest love will persuade me into matrimony" showing how she would only settle for the greatest love, not the convenient kind of love. That's why I think this film is so exceptional and different then a lot of love stories today. Obviously the movie is shot in a different time period than other movies based on romance are today. Yet, there is a true love in this story that I think other romantic movies in this generation lack. But, I do believe that good romance movies are making a comeback. Stories filled with real love, not a selfish sort of love story, and that is exciting to me. -Megan O'Neal Read more from me at http://moviesfrommyeyes101.blogspot.com/

Matthew, who plays Mr Darcy, is handsome and charming, and I always liked him. Keira, who plays Elizabeth, well, I never really grew to like. It seemed like what she said did not match her personality...she said all the things Lizzy would say, but she just wasn't Lizzy.Also, I do want to point out the BBC version has the luxury of being a mini-series and has time to build character and storyline, so that was good. This movie just seemed rushed and also the characters weren't all to satisfying. I wanted more on the family dynamic and their flaws, which supposedly made Darcy see them as threats to Lizzy's happiness and security. This movie did not seem to point that out as much, while the BBC version was satisfying in that aspect and made what Darcy wrote about and though about the family more justified. As a quick movie highlighting the book's highs and lows for a general audience, it does the trick, but for a Jane Austenite, an avid fan who's always searching for better versions, this one just stopped satisfying me fully. I still would briefly eye it to get a fix, especially for Matthew, but for a full rendering of the book and all it's plots and arcs and characters, I'd watch another version or the mini-series.

The novel Pride and Prejudice is a humorous satire about women's dependence on marriage for economic security. In the 2005 movie rendition of it, Joe Wright, a relatively new director, attempted to capture the feeling of it in a condensed two-hour film. Though it is considered by many to be the best version of the movie, it ultimately fails to capture the novel's satirical message about women marrying for financial safety and plays out more like a romantic drama with a corny ending due to its underdeveloped or differently developed characters and lack or change of a few important scenes. The movie Pride and Prejudice had several scenes omitted or changed to make it fit into the two-hour average movie runtime. The whole rendition of the movie is a cliché. In shortening the time to tell the entire story, Joe Wright turned a satire about the women's views on marriage into just another love story. Evidence of this can be seen as early as the first ball. In the movie, Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy make eye contact for a moment and it is evident by her facial expression that she is going to end up with him at the end. This is a cliché seen in most romance movies. Also, in the scenes where Mr. Darcy professes his love to Elizabeth, it rains as she turns him down and says he's the last man she would ever marry. They are not outside in the rain when this happens in the novel. This makes the entire scene seem more dreary and sad where the novel is humorous and satirical. The ending to this movie is a romantic cliché also. Elizabeth and Darcy are outside after they get married and are about to kiss when a conversation happens in which Mr. Darcy professes that he is completely happy with her in heart-warming way. Give me a break. The ending is so corny in the movie that it kills the entire satirical point of the novel. All these clichés turn the movie into a heart-wrenching love story rather than a humorous satire. A few of the characters in the movie are developed differently than the characters in the novel. One of these characters is Elizabeth. She is kind and has a good humor in the novel, whereas in the movie she is rude and ill-tempered. Darcy is also seen as a comic character in the movie, which he was most certainly not in the novel. And speaking of characterization, it was virtually nonexistent for Wickham in the movie. Whoever wrote the scripts for these characters and was in charge of their characterization failed to capture them in the way Austen did in the novel. This makes the entire movie feel like a romantic drama. It does not have the feel of the satire that was created by Jane Austen in the novel. Though Joe Wright successfully recreates the events of the novel Pride and Prejudice in his movie, he fails to capture the feeling of it. The movie has underdeveloped or differently characterized characters and condensed scenes with some actually omitted. With this, Wright creates a romantic drama instead of the humorous satire created by Austen in the novel.
